conclusion: Objects A and B are pieces of fabric that are initially suspended in the air.
Under each fabric there are rigid blocks: Under A: blocks C (the short gray block) and D (the taller green block). Under B: blocks E (the tall green block) and F (the blue block).

premise: Objects A and B are initially suspended in the air.
conclusion: When the fabrics are released, gravity accelerates them downward.
The fabrics reach the tops of the blocks first. They collide, lose speed, and begin to drape.

premise: The fabrics collide with the tops of the blocks and begin to drape.
conclusion: Because the cloth is flexible, Fabric A spreads over the tops of C and D, then sags between and around them until it either touches the tabletop or reaches equilibrium in mid-air (depending on its size). Fabric B does the same over E and F.

premise: The cloth spreads over the tops of the blocks.
conclusion: Friction and the pins/weights sewn into the cloth corners keep each fabric from sliding off the blocks once the motion stops.

premise: Friction and pins/weights keep the fabric in place.
conclusion: After a short time the system comes to rest: each cloth sits motionless, naturally draped over its corresponding pair of blocks.

premise: Each cloth sits motionless, naturally draped over its corresponding pair of blocks.
conclusion: Both pieces of fabric will fall, hit the blocks underneath them, and then drape / hang around those blocks until they settle into a stable, motionless shape over C–D and over E–F, respectively.
